{/* Hero Section */}
A02:2021

Cryptographic Failures

Formerly known as "Sensitive Data Exposure," this vulnerability focuses on failures related to cryptography which often lead to exposure of sensitive data.

#2 OWASP Rank
High Severity
Widespread Prevalence
🔐
Data Protection
{/* Overview Section */}

Understanding Cryptographic Failures

Cryptographic failures occur when sensitive data is not properly protected through encryption, leading to exposure of passwords, credit card numbers, health records, and other confidential information.

🚨 Critical Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive user data
  • Identity theft and financial fraud
  • Regulatory compliance violations (GDPR, HIPAA)
  • Reputation damage and legal consequences
1
Sensitive Data Passwords, credit cards, PII
2
Weak Encryption Outdated algorithms or poor implementation
3
Data Exposure Attackers access unencrypted data
{/* Common Failures */}

Common Cryptographic Failures

🔓

Weak Encryption Algorithms

Using outdated algorithms like MD5, SHA-1, or weak ciphers that can be easily broken.

Using DES or RC4 instead of AES-256
📧

Data in Transit Exposure

Failing to use TLS or using weak SSL/TLS configurations that expose data during transmission.

HTTP instead of HTTPS for sensitive data
💾

Data at Rest Exposure

Storing sensitive data without encryption or using weak encryption keys and poor key management.

Plain text passwords in database
{/* Prevention Section */}

Prevention Strategies

🛡️ Encryption Standards

Use Strong Algorithms

Implement AES-256 for symmetric encryption and RSA-2048+ for asymmetric encryption.

Proper TLS Configuration

Enforce HTTPS with modern TLS versions and strong cipher suites.

🔑 Key Management

Secure Key Storage

Use hardware security modules (HSM) or cloud KMS for key management.

Key Rotation

Implement regular key rotation policies and secure key distribution.

); }; export default CryptographicFailures;
